title: 104_hr4053
content: The Act titled "Emergency Wheat Gluten Act of 1996" imposes temporary duties until a final determination is made. The Emergency Wheat Gluten Act of 1996 imposes a 25 percent ad valorem duty on wheat gluten imported from the European Union, as described in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule. This duty applies for a specified period after the enactment of the Act. The investigation may be suspended based on specific dates or final determinations by the Commission under the Tariff Act of 1930. Refunds or collections of duty differences are handled according to the Tariff Act of 1930. SEC. 3. INITIATION OF INVESTIGATION. Initiation of Investigation: The administering authority must start an investigation within 30 days of the enactment of this Act regarding the importation and sales of wheat gluten into the United States. The provisions of the Tariff Act of 1930 apply to this countervailing duty investigation, with certain exceptions. The investigation initiated under subsection (a) may be suspended as per section 704 of the Act if certain requirements are met, including notifying relevant committees and parties at least 30 days before the suspension. The administering authority must notify relevant committees and parties of the intention to suspend the investigation, consult with the committees, and provide a copy of the proposed agreement explaining how it will be enforced and meet the requirements of the Tariff Act of 1930. This process permits all interested parties to submit comments and information before the investigation is suspended. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "administering authority" refers to the entity defined in the Tariff Act of 1930, while "Commission" specifically denotes the United States International Trade Commission.
